First, I'd like to (sincerely) thank [planetscape] for creating [id://792202]. I have removed the follow paragraph from it:

In reading through these, one discovers an interesting fact: even when suggestions for syntax highlighting/PerlTidying (or otherwise mucking about with others' content) get a favorable consensus from the general monkulace, it still doesn't result in the change being enacted. You'd probably need to have not only a very strong case, but a huge groundswell of popular support and substantial buy-in from the site [gods|powers-that-be] to get such a change proposal pushed through to reality.

In future, I suggest [planetscape] make use of SDC tools for getting feedback and colaborating more (such as, but not limited to, an alphafaqlet). The above paragraph displays a fundamental misunderstanding or perhaps just misinterpretation of how features get implemented at PerlMonks. A "groundswell" is not required. Nor is "a huge groundswell" even sufficient. Nor is "substantial buy-in from the [[gods]]" hardly ever a factor in things that actually get implemented.

Features mostly get implemented at PerlMonks when somebody JFDI by creating a patch and then one of the [gods] JFDI by applying it. I don't recall any patches related to syntax coloring nor was I able to find any. Not that this is surprising to me for a fairly wide realm of reasons including javascript security issues at PerlMonks, server load issues, and having not even seen a consensus on what syntax coloring makes sense here (some want reformatting of code, some want "what stackoverflow has" which wouldn't work very well on Perl code, others want a Perl-specific highlighter and to burden posters to the site with declaring whether each item they post is appropriate to be highlighted or not).

Although I'm not going to take the time to search through the linked threads trying to find which thread(s) [planetscape] was referring to, I'd be quite surprised if her use of "consensus from the general monkulace" wasn't also misguided / mistaken. "Fact" and "enacted" also appear misused, IMO.

It would have been more appropriate for [planetscape] to include the sentiments from that paragraph in her (personal) node in the thread rather than making it a part of official site documentation without any apparent review or consultation. Perhaps the uncharacteristic lapse in judgement was even motivated by pent-up frustration that might be eased by such open expression? (Obviously, I can't know [planetscape]'s emotional state and I don't pretend to.)

I appreciate that there appears to have been some effort put into avoiding inappropriate tone. Unfortunately, it mostly just makes the text come across as passive agressive (I wish I could find a more precise adjective but hope this one is still understandable) rather than appropriate for site documentation, IMHO.

A more appropriate notation to add to that FAQ would be highlighting how syntax coloring can already be had rather easily by anybody who wants to enable it (with several choices to pick from). (No, I have not taken the time to read up on those options to the point that I could properly add such a notation.)

[jdporter], [localtime://2009-03-26 07:49:48]

I think an essential issue here is striking a balance between announcing all the "interesting" changes we make, and keeping the volume of announcements under control so that monks don't get overwhelmed and miss interesting changes. For this reason, we exclude from [Tidings] any changes which only affect [Cabal] members.

We also omit very small enhancements (for example, adding links or anchors — [pmdev://750932], [pmdev://745622] — or adding "silent chatterbox" quips and such like as — [pmdev://744732]). I would say this applies to bug fixes as well; for example, I wouldn't announce that we fixed the "logout link" bug which used to exist on the "PerlMonks" button of the [href:///bare/?node_id=3193|full-page chat upper frame].

One very general rule of thumb is that if every single monk who reads of a change goes "so what", then maybe an announcement isn't warranted. :-)
OTOH, if a change is made in response to a request (as broached via a [PMD] post, for example), then an official announcement of the change seems justified, even if it isn't particularly interesting.

Changes which impact off-site automation tools should be considered critical, and should always be announced. The runner of such a tool doesn't want to find, two days too late, that his bot hasn't been getting PerlMonks info because the feed structure silently changed. Of course, for such things, some advance notice would be nice, so a [PMD] post about it before effecting the change would be nice. :-)
